text: 10x,just for my case.It would be much easier if there was a way to find the name from master page directive set in the view itself from FindView.

I made use of the "Custom View Engine" version except that I removed the condition "if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(masterName)){...} so that it uses the Page directive's MasterPageFile attribute unless a masterPage is specified in the ActionResult.
Better yet, View() has an overload allowing you to define the MasterPage to be used.  msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd470743.aspx

Yes - but that isn't optimal because you want to specify the master page in the view itself, why should the controller care about that? That's a problem because  you can have more than one master page in an application, and there is no way to detect what master page a view has asked for from anywhere other than the base Page class in WebForms.
Thanks for making this post - I was almost considering some silly workaround when I realised I might be able to change the MasterPage dynamically, quick Google later and there you are!
